In 1985, Fox starred in the iconic science fiction film "Back to the Future" trilogy, playing the role of Marty McFly, a time-traveling teenager who embarks on a series of adventures with his friend Doc Brown (Christopher Lloyd). The trilogy became a massive commercial success and cemented Fox's status as a Hollywood star.

Throughout the 1990s, Fox continued to act in various films and television shows, including "Teen Wolf" (1985), "The Secret of the Kells" (1986), and "Spin City" (1996-2002), where he played the role of New York City Mayor Mike Flaherty.

In 1998, Fox announced that he had been diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, a neurological disorder that affects movement and balance. Despite this diagnosis, Fox continued to act, writing, and advocating for Parkinson's research and awareness. He founded the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research in 2000, which has since become one of the largest non-profit organizations dedicated to finding a cure for the disease.

Fox has written several books, including his memoirs "Lucky Man: A Memoir" (2002) and "Always Looking Up: The Adventures of an Incurable Optimist" (2009). He has also been involved in various charitable initiatives, including the Michael J. Fox Foundation's "Team Fox" cycling team, which raises funds for Parkinson's research.

Throughout his career, Michael J. Fox has received numerous awards and accolades, including an Emmy Award, a Golden Globe Award, and a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Despite his struggles with Parkinson's, Fox remains an inspiration to millions, using his platform to raise awareness and funds for research, while also continuing to inspire and entertain audiences through his work.
